Appendix 1 Proactive Identification Guidance Appendix 2 TEP pro forma
The purpose of this policy is to ensure that all health care providers are aware and follow the key ethical and legal issues surrounding treatment escalation plans (TEP).

TEP forms are used to encourage clinical decision-making for all patients in whom acute clinical deterioration is a foreseeable risk. They are also used as part of advance care planning in those patients with a possible life expectancy of under one year (e.g. patients that you would not be surprised if they died within the next 6-12 months).
TEP forms are to be used for appropriate adult (18yrs and over) inpatients within MEHT.

The TEP guides the level of life sustaining therapeutic interventions or actions that medical and nursing staff should ensure occur for each patient and aim to prevent inappropriate and undignified interventions on those for whom these interventions offer no realistic benefit.

It is always a Health Professionals duty to act in a patient's best interest. All treatment and care that is appropriate for a patient will be offered. For the vast majority of patients the over-riding aim is to return them to their pre-illness level of health, or as near as possible.

Nevertheless, it is not an appropriate goal of medicine to prolong life at all costs with no regard to its quality or the burdens of treatment on the patient. Moreover, to begin a therapeutic intervention that the patient will clearly not survive is not in their best interests. This implies that not all treatment modalities are appropriate for every patient. For all patients we must ensure that appropriate resuscitation policies which respect patients' rights are in place, understood by all relevant staff, and accessible to those who need them.

Much of the guidance in respect of treatment and care towards the end of life encourages early involvement and good communication with the patient. All the guidance acknowledges that these discussions are often difficult and sensitive as it most likely involves deciding whether to start or stop potentially life-sustaining treatments such as CPR. However, involving a patient in advance care planning, where they are willing and able, puts them back at the centre of their care.

The guidelines that follow identify the key ethical and legal issues that should inform all these decisions. These basic principles are the same for all patients, in all settings, but differences in clinical and personal circumstances make it essential that all TEP decisions are made on an individual basis.

Decisions about CPR are sensitive and complex and should be undertaken by experienced members of the healthcare team. Each directorate should ensure that their clinical staff have the training and maintain knowledge and skills to undertake discussions about TEP when needed.
This document refers to the escalation of care appropriate to each patient up to and until a cardiac arrest occurs (where the heart stops beating).
For decisions and information regarding cardiopulmonary resuscitation please refer to the DNACPR policy.
This policy must be readily available and understood by all relevant staff and should also be available to the public.
Mid Essex is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
This policy applies to all adult patients admitted to Mid Essex Hospitals
This policy specifically excludes children and young people i.e. those under 18 years of age.
Chief Executive
The Chief Executive has overall responsibility for ensuring that resources and systems are in place for the management of the risks associated with treatment escalation planning.
Chief Medical Officer
The Chief Medical Officer is responsible for ensuring that resources and mechanisms are in place for the implementation, monitoring and review of this policy.
Medical Officers
Individual ‘treatment escalation plans' are the responsibility of the consultant in charge of the patient's care, following discussion with the patient or carer and the multidisciplinary team.
Deteriorating Patient Group (DPG)
Responsibilities include;
Ensuring adherence to various national guidelines and standards;
Formulating and updating treatment escalation plan policies;
To review annual audit of TEP orders and develop and monitor action plans to address any identified deficiencies.
Clinical Lead for Resuscitation
Will ensure that policy and practice match national standards;
Will lead the DPG discussions relating to the audit of TEP decisions.
Resuscitation Department
To act as advisors on treatment escalation plans
To work with the Clinical Audit Department to carry out an annual audit of ‘treatment escalation plans' reporting to the DPG
Clinical Staff
To ensure they comply with this policy;
To report any issues relating to this policy to their manager.
Health professionals are aware that decisions about treatment escalation planning raise very sensitive and potentially distressing issues for patients and those people emotionally close to them.
These decisions are best made before crisis necessitates a hurried decision in an emergency setting.

Treatment escalation planning should be undertaken only by those who have the necessary training and experience. Within MEHT consultants who routinely participate in acute on calls and thereby have the experience and knowledge necessary to make such decisions should deliver this.
Each directorate should ensure that their clinical staff have the training and maintain knowledge and skills to undertake these discussions.
Treatment escalation planning includes the spectrum of medical interventions that will or will not be provided in the event of significant and predictable clinical deterioration in a patient.

Treatment escalation plans are individualised for each patient and are necessary to ensure that patients are involved in the decision making process and have tailored therapeutic goals that are in line with their needs and wishes.
Differences in clinical and personal circumstances make it essential that all decisions relating to treatment escalation planning are made on an individual basis.
For many people receiving care, in hospital or in the community the likelihood of significant clinical deterioration resulting in the need for advanced organ support to sustain life is small.

If the need for advanced organ support is not predicted or reasonably foreseeable in the current circumstances or treatment episode, it is not necessary to initiate discussions about TEP with patients.
However even if the risk is low, then clinicians should be prepared to discuss the spectrum of life support available to patients in an honest and transparent fashion if they request it.
In other cases there is an identifiable risk of significant clinical deterioration, either because of
a) an advanced, progressive, incurable condition
b) general frailty and co-existing conditions that mean they are expected to die within 12 months (see appendix 1)
c) existing conditions if they are at risk of dying from a sudden acute crisis in their condition
or
d) life-threatening acute conditions caused by sudden catastrophic events (such as overwhelming sepsis)

The TEP needs to be made in advance of clinical deterioration such that junior medical and nursing staff can provide care appropriate to the patient's needs in the event of clinical deterioration when the senior clinician who is responsible for the patient may not be present.

TEP decisions should only be made by a doctor with the necessary skills and experience ST1 and above who is responsible for the clinical care of the patient following a full clinical assessment and consultation with the patient.

For a TEP decision to be made it is vital that not only is the clinical information regarding acute and current illnesses assessed, but also accurate and quantitative documentation of their functional status.
The statement of ‘independent of all ADL's' should not be used to determine escalation planning as it does not give any meaningful
information regarding an individual's life and activities on a day to day practise and represents poor practise in history taking.
For almost all patients except in the absolute emergency – there is often time to gather this information from their next of kin.

Some patients who have capacity decide that, on balance, they have reached the stage where treatment to prolong their life would be inappropriate and is not desired. Some identify a point in the future after which they do not want treatment, or specific circumstances in which they do not want treatment, and refuse further interventions in an advance decision. Supporting patients and their wishes is the gold standard of a successful TEP.
Clinicians discussing or communicating decisions regarding escalation should consider the following pointers:
Patients should be offered as much, or as little, information as they want
Information should be provided in a manner and format which patients can understand; this may include the need for an interpreter
Questions should be answered as honestly as possible.
The person's individual circumstances and the most up-to-date evidence and professional guidance must be considered carefully before any treatment escalation plans are made.
A TEP should be made in line with DNACPR decisions in an honest and transparent fashion with a thorough understanding of the clinical deterioration envisaged.

Ineligibility for multi-organ ICU support is not in itself a justification for an automatic DNACPR decision and a DNACPR decision is not justification for withholding or not providing life-sustaining therapies in appropriate cases.

The TEP should be subject to review based on the person's individual circumstances. In the setting on an acute illness, review should be sufficiently frequent to allow a change of decision (in either direction) in response to the person's clinical progress or any change in their expressed wishes. In the setting of end-of-life care for a progressive, irreversible condition there may be little or no need for review of the TEP.
Transfer of the patient to a different location (including transfer within a healthcare establishment) should trigger a review of the TEP decision

There may be exceptional cases where a patient has a TEP in place but cardiac or respiratory arrest occurs in circumstances that do not match those envisaged, and the cause of the deterioration is easily

reversible, such as choking, anaphylaxis or a blocked tracheostomy. In this situation a TEP does not override clinical judgement and active management of this acutely reversible condition should occur.

Where there is no explicit clinical decision in advance on the appropriateness or otherwise of escalating treatment and the express wishes of the patient are unknown and cannot be ascertained, there should be a presumption that all reasonable attempts to improve the patient's condition should be considered
In this situation lifesaving treatment should be started, whilst all possible efforts are made to obtain more information to guide further decision-making.

There may be some cases where treatment is started on this basis. After that further information may become available such as prior TEP or an ADRT (advance decision to remove treatment). In such circumstances it may make continued treatment inappropriate.
If there is genuine doubt or disagreement about the most appropriate course of action, further senior clinical opinion should be sought.
Communication and documentation of TEP decisions – when the patient has capacity
Communication and the provision of information are essential parts of good quality care.

Adult patients are presumed to have capacity to make decisions for themselves unless the contrary is proven. For those who lack capacity it is equally important to ensure that decisions are made that comply with the law, in that they are in the best interests of the patient.

Patients have both ethical and legal rights to be involved in decisions that may affect them. When a patient with capacity is at foreseeable risk of clinical deterioration, they should be offered information about each point in the TEP and about their role in decision- making.

In order to determine whether the benefits of each therapy would be likely to outweigh the harms and burdens, or whether the level of recovery expected would be acceptable to the patient, there should be sensitive exploration of the patient's wishes, feelings, beliefs and values.

Policies and individual decisions about treatment escalation planning must comply with the Human Rights Act  In order to meet their obligations under the Act, healthcare professionals must be able to show that their decisions are compatible with the human rights set out in the Articles of the Convention.
Provisions particularly relevant to decisions including escalation planning include articles:
a) The right to life (Article 2),
b) The right to be free from inhuman or degrading treatment (Article 3)
c) The right to respect for privacy and family life (Article 8),
d) The right to freedom of expression, which includes the right to hold opinions and to receive information (Article 10) and
e) The right to be free from discriminatory practise in respect of these rights (Article 14).

In considering decisions about treatment in relation to the Act the courts have indicated that the degree of patient involvement required by Article 8 depends on the particular circumstances of the case and notably the nature of the decisions to be taken.

In relation to decisions about CPR the courts have stated that there should be a presumption in favour of patient involvement and that there need to be convincing reasons not to involve the patient. Ethically the same principle stands for treatment escalation planning.

Where the decision was a shared decision with the patient (or their welfare attorney), based on a balance of benefits against harms and burdens of life sustaining treatment, any revision should be a shared decision with the patient (or those close to the patient if the patient has subsequently lost capacity), or where this is not practicable or not appropriate the reasons should be documented clearly.

When it is clear that someone is dying from an advanced, irreversible condition, clinicians must be sensitive to the patient's emotional and physical condition and to fluctuations therein. Conversations about treatment escalation planning are often difficult for clinicians and for patients (and those close to or representing patients), but must not be avoided just because they are difficult or because they may cause some unavoidable distress.

Whilst there should be presumption in favour of informing patients of escalation planning in the event of clinical deterioration, some people make it clear that they do not wish to talk about dying or discuss their end-of-life care, including decisions relating to CPR. When such wishes are expressed they should be respected.
It is poor practise to force TEP or CPR discussion of patients who stated clearly that they do not want them.

If a TEP decision is made and there has been no discussion with the patient because he or she has indicated a clear desire to avoid such discussion, this must be documented in the health record and the reasons must be recorded. As with any other aspect of care, health professionals must be able to justify their actions.
Any such refusal by a patient to discuss a treatment escalation plan should be documented clearly, together with a plan to ensure that optimal care of the patient is not compromised by that refusal.

In a minority of cases, trying to explain a TEP decision, where escalation of current therapies will not work, will impose an unnecessary burden by causing such distress that the person suffers harm, which may be physical or psychological. The reasons for not explaining a decision in such circumstances must be documented fully.
Where a patient or those close to the patient disagree with a TEP decision, a second opinion should be offered and all members of the multi disciplinary team should respect this process.

A TEP applies only up to the point that a patient suffers a cardiac arrest (their heart stops beating), however, clearly for an honest and meaningful discussion to occur, cardiopulmonary resuscitation should also be discussed.

Clear and full documentation of decisions relating to TEP, the decisions themselves and the discussions that informed those decisions are an important part of high quality care. Notes should be made in the healthcare record beyond simply completing the TEP form.
Health care professionals discussing and communicating TEP decisions to patients, and those close to them, should:
Offer as much information as is wanted (with due regard for the patients wishes concerning confidentiality)
Be open and honest
Use clear, unambiguous language
Use a combination of verbal discussion and information in printed or other formats
Provide information in formats which people can understand, this may include the need for an interpreter or easy-to-read formats
Provide information that is accurate and consistent
Check understanding
Where possible, have conversations about decisions in an appropriate environment and allow adequate time for discussion and reflection.
Communication and the provision of information are essential parts of good quality care.

Decision-making capacity refers to the everyday ability that individuals possess to make decisions or to take actions that influence their life, from simple decisions about what to have for breakfast, to far-reaching decisions about serious medical treatment, for example treatment escalation planning. In a legal context it refers to a person's ability to do something, including making a decision, which may have legal consequences for the person themselves or for other people.

Patients over 16 years of age are presumed to have capacity to make decisions themselves unless the contrary is proven. Individuals are, however, considered legally unable to make decisions for themselves where they are unable to:
Understand the information relevant to the decision;
Retain that information;
Use or weigh that information as part of the process of making the decisions; or
Communicate the decisions whether by talking, using sign language or by other means.

Policies and individual decisions about treatment escalation planning must comply with the Human Rights Act  In order to meet their obligations under the Act, healthcare professionals must be able to show that their decisions are compatible with the human rights set out in the Articles of the Convention.
Provisions particularly relevant to decisions including escalation planning include articles:
a) The right to life (Article 2),
b) The right to be free from inhuman or degrading treatment (Article 3)
c) The right to respect for privacy and family life (Article 8),
d) The right to freedom of expression, which includes the right to hold opinions and to receive information (Article 10) and
e) The right to be free from discriminatory practise in respect of these rights (Article 14).

This section explains who should be consulted when adults lack capacity and explains the main provisions of the Mental Capacity Act 2005 (England and Wales) and the Adults with Incapacity (Scotland) Act 2000 concerning proxy decision-makers. Further details are available in the Trust's Mental Capacity Act Policy and the Safeguarding Vulnerable Adults Policy.
Adults who lack capacity where:
There is no welfare attorney or other legal surrogate and
They have not made a valid and applicable advance decision refusing life sustaining therapies

Where a patient has not appointed a welfare attorney, had a welfare guardian or deputy appointed or made an advance decision the treatment decision rests with the most senior clinician responsible for the patients care.

The decision as to what forms of life sustaining therapy are appropriate must be made on the basis of the patients best interest. A Mental Capacity Act (MCA) 2 form must be filled in on behalf of those patients for significant decisions relating to their on-going care.

Those close to the patient must be consulted about TEP decisions that are made on a balance of benefits and risks, in particular to determine any previously expressed wishes and what level or chance of recovery or risk that patient would have been likely to consider acceptable. However if specific life sustaining therapies e.g. invasive ventilation would not be successful in being able to achieve any hope of survival, then those close to the patient should be offered explanation of why decisions about why these decisions are made, and should be informed of the resulting TEP decisions and of the reasons for making it in the patient's specific circumstances.
These conversations should take place in the context of established and agreed goals of care for the patient.

In England and Wales the Mental Capacity Act requires that best- interests decisions must include seeking the views of anyone named by the patient as someone to be consulted, and anyone engaged in caring for the person or with an interest in the patient's welfare. Under the Act, all healthcare professionals must act in the best interests of a patient who lacks capacity.

It should be made clear to those close to the patient that their role is not to take decisions on behalf of the patient, but to help the healthcare team to make an appropriate decision in the patient's best interests. Relatives and others close to the patient should be assured that their views on what the patient would want will be taken into account in decision-making but that they cannot insist on a treatment or on withholding or withdrawal of treatment.

If the patient lacks capacity and has nobody else who is willing and appropriate to represent them or be consulted in the process of deciding on the appropriateness of life sustaining treatments then the decision maker has a duty to seek the input of an Independent Mental Capacity Advocate (IMCA)

It is important that TEP decisions are not delayed inappropriately (and the quality of care for the patient compromised thereby) if it is not practical and appropriate to contact the patient's family members, or other carers, immediately to discuss a best interest decision or to have decisions explained to them regarding escalation or not of life sustaining therapies. In this situation the senior healthcare professional responsible for the patients care should:
Record fully their reasons for not explaining the decision to those close to the patient at that time
Ensure that there is on-going active review of the decision and
Ensure that those close to the patient are informed at the earliest practicable and appropriate opportunity

The fact that it may be inconvenient or undesirable to inform those close to the patient of a decision at a particular time does not, in itself, meet the threshold for it being not practical or appropriate to inform them.

Great care must be taken when people other than the patient make decisions that involve an element of quality-of-life assessment, because there is a risk that health professionals or those close to the patient may see things from their own perspective and allow their own views and wishes to influence their decision, rather than those of the patient. These considerations should always be undertaken from the patient's perspective.

An important factor is whether the patient (if they had capacity) would regard the level of possible recovery acceptable, taking into account the invasiveness of life sustaining therapies and their likelihood of success in the individual circumstances under consideration not whether it would be acceptable to the healthcare team or to those close to the patient, nor what they would want if they were in the patient's position.
People with a welfare attorney or court-appointed deputy or guardian

If a patient lacks capacity and has a personal welfare attorney (also described as an attorney for health and welfare) or a deputy (in England and Wales), it will be necessary to discuss matters relating to treatment escalation planning with them.

If a patient has a property and affairs attorney (or a person with enduring power of attorney), it may well be that they should be consulted as a person close to the patient, but they do not have the same powers as a personal welfare attorney in relation to decisions about medical treatment. The court of protection may appoint a welfare deputy with similar powers to a welfare attorney, although a deputy does not have the power to refuse life-sustaining treatment.

The aim should be, whenever practical and appropriate, to explain, discuss and agree the intended plan of treatment for the patient, including the provision or not of life sustaining therapies. All reasonable steps should be taken to contact them in order to do that.

If the attorney or deputy is not contactable or not available for consultation and an immediate decision is needed to ensure best possible treatment and avoid harm, clinicians have a duty of care to make and record the decision that they believe to be in the patients best interests, based on all available information, and then to consult the attorney or deputy at the earliest practicable time.

Neither welfare attorneys nor deputies can demand treatment that is clinically inappropriate. Where treatment escalation plans are based on a balance of benefit and risk however, the attorney or deputy must be consulted, unless an immediate decision is needed and they are not contactable or available for consultation.

A personal welfare attorney is only empowered to make decisions on behalf of a patient regarding life sustaining therapy if their power of attorney document states specifically that the personal welfare attorney has the power to consent to or refuse life-sustaining treatment.
If the welfare attorney makes that decision, it is a binding decision that clinicians must respect, unless;
The circumstances of the clinical deterioration are not those envisaged when the advance decision regarding treatment escalation planning were discussed with and made by the welfare attorney, or
The clinician has good reason to believe that the decision made by the welfare attorney was not made on the basis of the patients best interests.

Where there is disagreement between the healthcare team and an appointed welfare attorney or court-appointed guardian about treatment escalation planning, and this cannot be resolved through discussion and a second clinical opinion, the Court of Protection may be asked to make a declaration. More information about welfare attorneys and the Mental Capacity Act can be found in the Mental Capacity Act code of practice.

Adults with capacity have the right to refuse any medical treatment, even if that refusal results in their death. Where healthcare teams believe that medical interventions will be successful in prolonging life, discussion should take place with the patients to determine their views and wishes regarding treatment.

If patients decide that they do not wish to have various intervention or therapies should they deteriorate, this should be documented carefully in the hospital records and steps should be taken to ensure that this is communicated appropriately to those who need to know.

Patients are not obliged to justify their decisions, but health professionals usually wish to discuss the implications of a refusal of treatment with patients in order to ensure that the decision is based on accurate information and not on a misunderstanding; however, they must take care not to pressure patients into accepting treatment that they do not want.

Some people may be happy for their refusal of life sustaining therapies (i.e. they do not wish to be invasively ventilated) to be documented in the health record by the healthcare team. In England and Wales, unless these records are signed by patients and the signature is witnessed, they are unlikely to meet the legal criteria for a valid advance decision and so some patients may prefer to make a formal, written advance decision.

Similarly, if patients are not currently being treated in a healthcare establishment and they wish to ensure that their wishes are respected, they may decide to make a formal, written Advance Decision to Refuse Treatment (ADRT) following the criteria stipulated in the Mental Capacity Act 2005 (England and Wales).
Life sustaining therapy must not be attempted if it is contrary to a valid and applicable ADRT (in England and Wales) made when the person had capacity.

in England and Wales advance decisions are covered by the Mental Capacity Act 2005. An ADRT refusing CPR or specific life sustaining therapies will be valid, and therefore legally binding on the healthcare team, if:
The person was  years old or over and had capacity when the decision was made
The decision is in writing, signed and witnessed
It includes a statement that the advance decision is to apply even if the patient's life is at risk
The advance decision has not been withdrawn
The person has not, since the advance decision was made, appointed a welfare attorney to make decisions about CPR or life sustaining therapies on their behalf
The person has not done anything clearly inconsistent with its terms
The current circumstances match those envisaged in the advance
decision.

If an ADRT does not meet these criteria but appears to set out a clear indication of the patient's wishes, it will not be legally binding but should be taken into consideration in determining the person's best interests.
The onus is on patients to ensure that healthcare teams are aware of the existence and content of any advance decision.
The Medical Records Service will only accept Living Wills or Advance Directives for patients who have current sets of case notes.
The Medical Records Service will not open a set of case notes for no other reason than to file a Living Will.
These documents will be returned to patients if their records are:
Microfilmed;
Archived at off-site storage;
Archived in any other archiving system.

The Trust does not guarantee that any Living Will or Advance Directive that is accepted for filing in the patient record will always be available although every effort will be made to ensure its availability.

Although an ADRT is not relevant until a person has lost capacity and may not come to light until a person has lost capacity, there should be a presumption that the individual had capacity when an advance decision was made unless there are grounds to suspect otherwise.

The onus is on patients to ensure that healthcare teams will be made aware of the existence and content of any ADRT. Ensuring that their family and others close to them are fully aware of the existence and location of the ADRT document will help to maximise the likelihood that their instructions are followed.

Health professionals must decide whether the ADRT is applicable to the circumstances that have arisen. Particular care will be needed where advance decisions have not been reviewed or updated for a long time and attention should be given to any relevant clinical developments or changes in the person's personal circumstances since decisions were made.

Where there is genuine doubt about the validity of an ADRT and when time permits, further enquiries should be made and, if necessary an application made to the Court of Protection (in England and Wales), the Sheriff Court (in Scotland) or the High Court (in Northern Ireland) for a judgment. In an emergency situation, where there is no time to investigate further, the presumption should be in favour of attempting CPR where this has a realistic chance of prolonging life.
If it is agreed that an ADRT is invalid or not applicable, the reasons should be documented.

In some circumstances it is necessary to revoke any previously made TEP decisions due to a change in their circumstances. In this situation the form should be scored through with X 2 lines using black ink and the words CANCELLED written within these lines. This must be signed by the clinician who is changing the TEP decision. The form must remain within the medical notes.
The reason for the change in status should be documented clearly in the medical notes and the relevant health care professionals informed.
Patients with capacity should also be informed of this decision as should the relevant parties in individuals who lack capacity.

The overall responsibility for decisions about treatment escalation planning rests with the consultant in charge of the patient's care. Effective communication is essential to ensure that decisions are understood by all those involved. All decisions about escalation planning should be communicated to all those involved in the patient's care.

Where care is shared, for example between hospital and general practice, or between general practice and a residential facility, the health professionals involved should discuss the issue with each other, and with other members of the healthcare team.

Wherever possible and appropriate, a decision about TEP should be agreed with the whole healthcare team. Teamwork and good communication are of crucial importance in the delivery of high-quality care.

Any decision about Treatment Escalation Planning must be recorded clearly in the patient's current health records and should be immediately accessible to all health professionals who may need to know it.

The health record should contain clear documentation of the decision, and sufficient detail to allow a healthcare professional facing an emergency situation to assess quickly and easily the basis on which the decision was made, the people involved (including the patient and if not, reasons why not), and others who have been informed of the decision.
The person who makes the TEP is responsible for ensuring that the decision is communicated effectively to other relevant health professionals in both primary and secondary care.
Any decisions about a TEP should be communicated between health professionals whenever a patient is transferred to another establishment or discharged home from a healthcare establishment.
The GMC places a professional obligation on doctors to follow agreed systems and ensure good communication

“You should check the handover arrangements where you work, and use the available systems and arrangements for information storage and exchange, to ensure that the agreed care plan is shared within the healthcare team, with both paid and unpaid carers outside the team and with other healthcare professionals involved in providing the patients care”.
The NMC places a professional obligation on nurses and midwives:
“You must keep your colleagues informed when you are sharing the care of others” and
“You have a duty to communicate fully and effectively with your colleagues ensuring that they have all the information they need about the people in their care”.

Any TEP decision must be tailored to the individual circumstances of the patient. It must not be assumed that the same decision will be appropriate for all patients with a particular condition. Decisions must not be made on the basis of assumptions based solely on factors such as the patient's age or disability. Blanket policies, for example to all patients in a hospice or nursing home or to patients above a certain age, are considered unethical and unlawful.

When assessing what life sustaining therapies are being offered or withheld for any patients, decision-makers must not be unduly influenced by any of their own pre-existing negative views about living with a particular condition or disability. The key issue to consider is not the decision-maker's view of the patient's disability or level of recovery that can reasonably be expected but an objective assessment of what is in the best interests of the patient.
This policy does not apply to patients under  years of age.

Staff are required to comply with the MEHT Confidentiality Policy and Sharing Patient Information Policy. Further information is available in the NHS Information Sharing: Guidance for Practitioners and Managers.

If patients have capacity their agreement must always be sought before sharing information including family members. It may also be helpful to ask patients with capacity who they want, or do not want, to be generally involved in decision-making if they become incapacitated (although it should be made clear that unless this person is formally appointed as a welfare attorney their role will be limited to providing information for the health professional who decides about treatment). Refusal by a patient with capacity to allow information to be disclosed to family or friends must be respected and documented clearly within the medical notes.

There should be clear, accurate and honest communication with the patient and (unless the patient has requested confidentiality) those close to the patient. Their understanding of what has been explained to them should be assessed. Where there is an attorney, deputy, guardian or IMCA involved in the discussions, relevant information should be provided to them to enable them to fulfil their role.

Where people lack capacity and their views on involving family and friends are not known, doctors may disclose confidential information to those close to the patient where this is necessary to discuss the patients care and make a decision that is in their best interests.
Documentation of TEP's will be subject to regular yearly clinical audit. This will be undertaken on an annual basis by the Resuscitation Department with the support of the Clinical Audit Team.
All TEP orders in place on each ward will be reviewed on a given day to assess compliance.

The findings of the audit will be reported to the DPG for review and approval. Where deficiencies are identified, the DPG will approve an action plan with identified leads and timescales and monitor progress with implementation at subsequent meetings.
The key findings of the report will be disseminated to the Patient Safety Group via the Integrated Learning report and to all staff via the electronic newsletter.
The report will be distributed to the Chief Medical Officer and Clinical Directors. Where local actions are indicated, progress will be monitored at Directorate Governance meetings.
This policy will be reviewed at three yearly intervals or sooner in response to issues identified as a result of local or national initiatives.
The policy will be uploaded on the Trust Website and Intranet.
The policy will be circulated to Divisional Directors to disseminate within their areas of responsibilities.
